question:
In each of the following sentences, there is one word underlined and one gap. From the list of words lettered A - D, choose the word that is most nearly opposite in meaning to the underlined word and that will, at the same time, correctly fill the gap in the sentences.

There isn't enough rice, so its importation is permitted whereas the importation of cement is.............
explanation:
permitted; authorize or allow (something)

prohibited; that has been forbidden; banned.

question:
In each of the following sentences, there is one word underlined and one gap. From the list of words lettered A - D, choose the word that is most nearly opposite in meaning to the underlined word and that will, at the same time, correctly fill the gap in the sentences.

The cast consisted of many famous actors and few.............ones.
explanation: famous; known about by many people.

question:
In each of the following sentences, there is one word underlined and one gap. From the list of words lettered A - D, choose the word that is most nearly opposite in meaning to the underlined word and that will, at the same time, correctly fill the gap in the sentences.

My grandfather, rather than being..........was often quite prejudiced in his opinions.
explanation:
prejudiced;  make biased. 

Impartial; treating all rivals or disputants equally.

question:
In each of the following sentences, there is one word underlined and one gap. From the list of words lettered A - D, choose the word that is most nearly opposite in meaning to the underlined word and that will, at the same time, correctly fill the gap in the sentences.

Both sides are very hopeful about the outcome of the peace talks, but observers are still very..........
explanation:
Hopeful; feeling or inspiring optimism about a future event.

pessimistic; tending to see the worst aspect of things or believe that the worst will happen.

question:
In each of the following sentences, there is one word underlined and one gap. From the list of words lettered A - D, choose the word that is most nearly opposite in meaning to the underlined word and that will, at the same time, correctly fill the gap in the sentences.

The clever lawyer exposed the facts that were obscure in the case, making the judge see beyond the.............
explanation:
obscure;  not clearly expressed or easily understood.

Obvious; easily perceived or understood; clear, self-evident, or apparent.

question:
In each of the following sentences, there is one word underlined and one gap. From the list of words lettered A - D, choose the word that is most nearly opposite in meaning to the underlined word and that will, at the same time, correctly fill the gap in the sentences.

It took me the whole day to summarize the lecturer's copious notes having been used to ............ones
explanation:
copious; abundant in supply or quantity. Plentiful

Scanty; small or insufficient in quantity or amount

question:
In each of the following sentences, there is one word underlined and one gap. From the list of words lettered A - D, choose the word that is most nearly opposite in meaning to the underlined word and that will, at the same time, correctly fill the gap in the sentences.

The principal of that school was demoted for his incompetence while several others were commended for their .............
explanation:
Incompetence; inability to do something successfully; ineptitude. 

Efficiency; (of a person) working in a well-organized and competent way.

question:
In each of the following sentences, there is one word underlined and one gap. From the list of words lettered A - D, choose the word that is most nearly opposite in meaning to the underlined word and that will, at the same time, correctly fill the gap in the sentences.

The official who disclosed the information he was supposed to ..............was sacked
explanation:
Disclosed; allow something hidden to be seen

Conceal; not allow to be seen; hide.

question:
In each of the following sentences, there is one word underlined and one gap. From the list of words lettered A - D, choose the word that is most nearly opposite in meaning to the underlined word and that will, at the same time, correctly fill the gap in the sentences.

The prosecutor argued his case vehemently but the defence lawyer responded................
explanation:
vehemently; in a forceful, passionate, or intense manner; with great feeling.

Feebly; in a way that lacks strength or force.

question:
In each of the following sentences, there is one word underlined and one gap. From the list of words lettered A - D, choose the word that is most nearly opposite in meaning to the underlined word and that will, at the same time, correctly fill the gap in the sentences.

While we expected it to be gradual, the process of transition to civilian rule came to an ........end.
explanation:
Gradual; taking place or progressing slowly or by degrees.

Abrupt; sudden and unexpected.

question:
From the words lettered A to D, choose the word that best completes each of the following sentences:

Alfred is afraid of his wife who has a very................size
explanation:
Alfred is afraid of his wife who has a very intimidating size

Intimidating; having a frightening, overawing, or threatening effect.

question:
From the words lettered A to D, choose the word that best completes each of the following sentences:
The government has imposed an..................on the importation of used vehicles.
explanation:
The government has imposed an embargo on the importation of used vehicles.

Embargo; an official ban on trade or other commercial activity with a particular country.

question:
From the words lettered A to D, choose the word that best completes each of the following sentences:

The corpse has been taken to the ...................
explanation:
The corpse has been taken to the mortuary

mortuary; a room or building in which dead bodies are kept, for hygienic storage or for examination, until burial or cremation.

question:
From the words lettered A to D, choose the word that best completes each of the following sentences:
In spite of the vicisitudes of life, she never........... from her plan

From the words lettered A to D, choose the word that best completes each of the following sentences:
When the solicitor told Awa to wait outside, she considered it ............to her dignity

From the words lettered A to D, choose the word that best completes each of the following sentences:
The meeting cannot start because we have not formed a .............

From the words lettered A to D, choose the word that best completes each of the following sentences:
The................of the asylum sang a song for the President.

From the words lettered A to D, choose the word that best completes each of the following sentences:
His appointment was................because of irregularities in his credentials.

From the words lettered A to D, choose the word that best completes each of the following sentences:

The seminar was held under the...........of the Government
explanation:
The seminar was held under the jurisdiction of the Government

jurisdiction ; the official power to make legal decisions and judgement.

question:
From the words lettered A to D, choose the word that best completes each of the following sentences:
The new car is very attractive but I doubt its.............
explanation:
The new car is very attractive but I doubt its durability

Durability; the ability to withstand wear, pressure, or damage

question:
After each of the following sentences, a list of possible interpretations of the sentence is given. Choose the interpretation that you consider most appropriate for each sentence.
Had it been possible to leave the country then, I would have done so. This means that
explanation: He didn't leave the country because it was impossible
options: I have not left the country and nothing will make me leave
I wanted to leave the country and I did
I will definitely leave the country one day
I would have liked to leave the country but I wasn't able to

question:
After each of the following sentences, a list of possible interpretations of the sentence is given. Choose the interpretation that you consider most appropriate for each sentence.
The proprietor and his accountant have had a running battle over the last financial report. This means that they have had
explanation: A confrontation which has gone on for a long time.
options: an argument which developed into a fight
a series of arguments on the report
to work hard to complete the report

question:
After each of the following sentences, a list of possible interpretations of the sentence is given. Choose the interpretation that you consider most appropriate for each sentence.
The proprietor and his accountant have had a running battle over the last financial report. This means that they have had
explanation: A confrontation which has gone on for a long time.
options: an argument which developed into a fight
a series of arguments on the report
to work hard to complete the report

question:
After each of the following sentences, a list of possible interpretations of the sentence is given. Choose the interpretation that you consider most appropriate for each sentence.
Unless you don't want to become a teacher, there's no reason for not accepting the sponsorship. This means that you should
explanation: The sponsorship is important and needed if you want to become a teacher
options: not refuse the sponsorship if you want to become a teacher
refuse the sponsorship if you want to because a teacher
not refuse the sponsorship if you don't want to become a teacher
refuse the sponsorship whether you want to be a teacher or not

question:
After each of the following sentences, a list of possible interpretations of the sentence is given. Choose the interpretation that you consider most appropriate for each sentence.
His chances of passing are very slim. This means that he
explanation: The speaker means you have little or no chance of success. Referring to a small probability

question:
After each of the following sentences, a list of possible interpretations of the sentence is given. Choose the interpretation that you consider most appropriate for each sentence.
We would never have followed his advice if we had known his reputation. This means that we
explanation: They only followed his advice because they didn't know who he really was
options: knew what people said about him so we refused to obey him
trusted him but did not need any advice
followed his advice because we didn't know him
trusted him but did not take his dvice

question:
After each of the following sentences, a list of possible interpretations of the sentence is given. Choose the interpretation that you consider most appropriate for each sentence.
All the handsome men left her cold. This means that
explanation: To bore or underwhelm one. to not make someone feel interested or excited
options: she needed to wear warm clothes
the men took no notice of her
she was not impressed by them

question:
After each of the following sentences, a list of possible interpretations of the sentence is given. Choose the interpretation that you consider most appropriate for each sentence.
Sulayman can't help shouting at the members of his team. This means that he
explanation: He keeps shouting at his team members  even when he doesn't want to
options: cannot help them without shouting at them
can't help them and can't stop shouting
can't control his emotions and keeps shouting

question:
After each of the following sentences, a list of possible interpretations of the sentence is given. Choose the interpretation that you consider most appropriate for each sentence.
Out of the blue came his letter inviting me to stay with him. This means that the letter came
explanation: without warning; unexpectedly.

question:
After each of the following sentences, a list of possible interpretations of the sentence is given. Choose the interpretation that you consider most appropriate for each sentence.

Femi spends precious time building castles in the air. This means that Femi
explanation: To create dreams, hopes, or plans that are impossible, unrealistic, or have very little chance of succeeding.
options: has made a lot of money

question:
After each of the following sentences, a list of possible interpretations of the sentence is given. Choose the interpretation that you consider most appropriate for each sentence.
Considering his huge salary, the Director ought to have built a house by now. This means that the Director
explanation: This means that the director doesn't own a house despite the increase in his income.
options: is not satisfied with his salary
has not built a house yet
earns a lot his house is still not ready
does not have enough money to build a house

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, below each of the following sentences, choose the word or group of words that is nearest in meaning to the underlined word as it is used in the sentence.

Nowadays, children are given much more latitude than before.
explanation: Latitude; scope for freedom of action or thought.

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, below each of the following sentences, choose the word or group of words that is nearest in meaning to the underlined word as it is used in the sentence.

My neighbour lives a humdrum life.
explanation:
Humdrum; lacking excitement or variety; boringly monotonous. 

monotonous; dull, tedious, and repetitious; lacking in variety and interest.

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, below each of the following sentences, choose the word or group of words that is nearest in meaning to the underlined word as it is used in the sentence.

The Manager described the new accountant as a man of impeccable character.
explanation: Impeccable; in accordance with the highest standards; faultless.

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, below each of the following sentences, choose the word or group of words that is nearest in meaning to the underlined word as it is used in the sentence.

The teacher sent the boy out of the class for his impertinence
explanation: Impertinence; lack of respect; rudeness.

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, below each of the following sentences, choose the word or group of words that is nearest in meaning to the underlined word as it is used in the sentence.

This book is the abridged version of the original.
explanation: Abridged; (of a piece of writing) having been shortened.

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, below each of the following sentences, choose the word or group of words that is nearest in meaning to the underlined word as it is used in the sentence.

After the riot, the streets were blocked with charred vehicles.
explanation: charred;  burnt and blackened.

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, below each of the following sentences, choose the word or group of words that is nearest in meaning to the underlined word as it is used in the sentence.

The thief's jail terms are to run concurrently.
explanation:
concurrently; at the same time; simultaneously

simultaneously; at the same time.

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:

The rapper's popularity is beginning to wane
explanation: Wane; become weak. To decrease in strength, intensity.

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, below each of the following sentences, choose the word or group of words that is nearest in meaning to the underlined word as it is used in the sentence.

The doctor told his patient about all the things that could impair his health.
explanation: Impair;  to weaken or damage (something, especially a faculty or function).

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, below each of the following sentences, choose the word or group of words that is nearest in meaning to the underlined word as it is used in the sentence.

The fat old woman looked comical in those trousers.
explanation:
Comical;  amusing, especially in a ludicrous or absurd way.

Ridiculous; deserving or inviting derision or mockery; absurd.

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:

When I arrived, I noticed that he.............the kitchen
explanation:
When I arrived, I noticed that he had swept the kitchen,

Swept is the past tense and past participle of  sweep, likewise had is the past tense and past participle of have

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:

He was dismissed because he ............. the cheque.
explanation: He was dismissed because he should not have issued  the cheque.

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:

Is there...............chalk in the classroom?
explanation:
Is there any chalk in the classroom?

Any; used to refer to one or some of a thing or number of things, no matter how much or how many.

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:

The last election resulted ..................a disaster for the Socialist Party
explanation: The last election resulted in a disaster for the Socialist Party

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:

The family..............dinner when we knocked at the door.
explanation:
The family was having dinner when we knocked at the door.

Having,means anything your doing right now at the moment.

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:

All................the president said was reported in the dailies.
explanation:
All that the president said was reported in the dailies.

''That'' is correct because ''all what'' is always wrong, and you should use either ''all that'' (or everything that, the words that, etc) or what. ''That'' is a relative pronoun like who/whom, whereas ''what'' is a nominal relative pronoun. The two words fulfill distinct grammatical parts, and cannot be interchanged

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:

Which of the two questions is..................?
explanation:
Which of the two questions is more difficult?

The rule is simple and has no exceptions. If you're only comparing two things, use comparatives like more and easier. If you're comparing more than two, use superlatives like most and easiest

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:

If it rains, the exhibition will be cancelled,.............?
explanation:
question tags turn a statement into a question. They are often used for checking information that we think we know is true.  

Usually if the main clause is positive, the question tag is negative, and if the main clause is negative, it's positive. For example: You don't like me (positive), do you (negative)?

from the  statement  ''If it rains, the exhibition will be cancelled, (positive)  wont it? (negative).? The speaker is certain the event would be canceled if it rains, the ''wont it?'' tag is to confirm there are all on the same page.

Question tag is used when we want to check something is true, or invite people to agree with us.

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:

The rent is too high;............,the house is not in a suitable location.
explanation:
The rent is too high; besides  the house is not in a suitable location.

Besides; means in addition to; apart from.

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:

Its about time your brother.............some attention to his English
explanation:
Its about time your brother paid some attention to his English.

Paid; is the past and past participle of pay. In this context it means to give (attention, respect, or a compliment) to (someone or something).

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:
The children's toys have all been stolen.

The correct answer is children's. Children is the plural of child. The same applies to women's; people's; men's. You would never write, “The childs' toy”, as “child” is singular, so the apostrophe would come before the s, “the child's toy”.

From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:

The ...............toys have all been stolen.
explanation:
The children's toys have all been stolen.

The correct answer is children's. Children is the plural of child. The same applies to women's; people's; men's. You would never write, “The childs' toy”, as “child” is singular, so the apostrophe would come before the s, “the child's toy”.

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:

Olu passed his examination .............he was a determined student
explanation:
Olu passed his examination because he was a determined student

Because; for the reason that; since.

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:

Your friend and mentor,.................his speech.
explanation: Your friend and mentor, has finished his speech.

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:

...............of you does this money belong to ?
explanation:
which of you does this money belong to ?

Which; is used for asking for information specifying one or more people or things from a definite set.

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:

One of the window panes.............yesterday
explanation:
One of the window panes was broken yesterday.

Both ''was'' and ''broken'' are in the past tense  and qualifies the noun ''Yesterday''

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:

No child................have drawn that picture.
explanation:
No child could have drawn that picture.

Could; is used to indicate possibility.

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:

The referee contemplated............the players off the pitch.
explanation: The referee contemplated sending the players off the pitch.

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:

The new road was completed on schedule..............the difficulties involved.
explanation:
The new road was completed on schedule despite the difficulties involved.

Despite; without being affected by; in spite of.

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:

..............of his evidence made no sense.
explanation:
much of his evidence made no sense.

much; a large amount.

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:
The celebrations were rounded.............with a firework display.
explanation:
The celebrations were rounded off with a firework display.

If you round off an activity with something, you end the activity by doing something that provides a clear or satisfactory conclusion to it.

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:
The members of the association were advised to cooperate with.............
explanation:
The members of the association were advised to cooperate with one another

one another; meaning each other

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:
The robe is.................long for the short minister
explanation:
The robe is.rather long for the short minister.

Rather; to a certain or significant extent or degree.

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:
The professors said that Ade was...............
explanation: The professors said that Ade was a student of great potential

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:
My friend asked me if I would like to go to las Palmas for a holiday and I said I...........
explanation:
My friend asked me if I would like to go to las Palmas for a holiday and I said I would

Would; expressing a desire or inclination.

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:
His father saw.............that Andrew got all the answers wrong
explanation: His father saw at a glance that Andrew got all the answers wrong

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:
Ali dropped the pot accidentally and it..............
explanation: Ali dropped the pot accidentally and it broke

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:
Every man, woman and child............asked to contribute.
explanation: Every man, woman and child was asked to contribute.

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:
That sack is.................heavy for us to lift
explanation: That sack is too heavy for us to lift

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:
If the school had been destroyed, we..............home.
explanation: If the school had been destroyed, we would have had to go home.

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:
The plane took off...................
explanation: The plane took off five minutes ago

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:
By Christmas, I..................for one year.
explanation: By Christmas, I shall have been working for one year.

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:

As they-.....................the thieves broke into the house
explanation: As they-were sleeping, the thieves broke into the house

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:

All the children were inoculated.............polio.
explanation:
All the children were inoculated against polio.

Against; in anticipation of and preparation for (a problem or difficulty).

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:

This plan is an alternative...........the last one
explanation: This plan is an alternative to the last one

question:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:
..............Ali did not win the elections, he has continued to award scholarships to the less privileged
explanation:
Although .Ali did not win the elections, he has continued to award scholarships to the less privileged.

Although; in spite of the fact that; even though.

question: In question numbered 78 above, choose the best option from letters A - D that best completes the gap.
explanation: Excursion; a short journey or trip, especially one taken as a leisure activity.

question: In question numbered 79 above, choose the best option from letters A - D that best completes the gap.
explanation: Heat; high temperature.

question: In question numbered 80 above, choose the best option from letters A - D that best completes the gap.
explanation: Furnace; an enclosed structure in which material can be heated to very high temperatures, e.g. for smelting metals.

question: In question numbered 81 above, choose the best option from letters A - D that best completes the gap.
explanation: Bellows; a device with an air bag that emits a stream of air when squeezed together with two handles, used for blowing air into a fire.

question: In question numbered 82 above, choose the best option from letters A - D that best completes the gap.
explanation: Embers; a small piece of burning or glowing coal or wood in a dying fire.

question: In question numbered 83 above, choose the best option from letters A - D that best completes the gap.
explanation: Pincers; a tool made of two pieces of metal with blunt concave jaws that are arranged like the blades of scissors, used for gripping and pulling things.

question: In question numbered 84 above, choose the best option from letters A - D that best completes the gap.
explanation: Anvil; a heavy iron block with a flat top and concave sides, on which metal can be hammered and shaped.

question: In question numbered 85 above, choose the best option from letters A - D that best completes the gap.
explanation: Hammer; a tool with a heavy metal head mounted at right angles at the end of a handle, used for jobs such as breaking things and driving in nails.

question: In question numbered 86 above, choose the best option from letters A - D that best completes the gap.
explanation: Sparks; a small fiery particle thrown off from a fire, alight in ashes, or produced by striking together two hard surfaces such as stone or metal.

question: In question numbered 87 above, choose the best option from letters A - D that best completes the gap.
explanation: Bowl; a round, deep dish or basin used for food or liquid.

question: In question numbered 88 above, choose the best option from letters A - D that best completes the gap.
explanation: Habitat; the natural home or environment of an animal, plant, or other organism.

question: In question numbered 89 above, choose the best option from letters A - D that best completes the gap.
explanation: Damage; physical harm that impairs the value, usefulness, or normal function of something.

question: In question numbered 90 above, choose the best option from letters A - D that best completes the gap.
explanation: Specie; a group of living organisms consisting of similar individuals capable of exchanging genes or interbreeding.

question: In question numbered 91 above, choose the best option from letters A - D that best completes the gap.
explanation: Parks; an area devoted to a specified purpose.

question: In question numbered 92 above, choose the best option from letters A - D that best completes the gap.
explanation: Game; an activity that one engages in for amusement or fun.

question: In question numbered 93 above, choose the best option from letters A - D that best completes the gap.
explanation: predator; an animal that naturally preys on others.

question: In question numbered 94 above, choose the best option from letters A - D that best completes the gap.
explanation: check; examine (something) in order to determine its accuracy, quality, or condition, or to detect the presence of something.

question: In question numbered 95 above, choose the best option from letters A - D that best completes the gap.
explanation: starvation; suffering or death caused by lack of food.

question: In question numbered 96 above, choose the best option from letters A - D that best completes the gap.
explanation: Tourist; a person who is travelling or visiting a place for pleasure.

question: In question numbered 97 above, choose the best option from letters A - D that best completes the gap.
explanation: Excite; cause (someone) to feel very enthusiastic and eager.

question: In question numbered 98 above, choose the best option from letters A - D that best completes the gap.
explanation: Gardens; a piece of ground adjoining a house, in which grass, flowers, and shrubs may be grown.

question: In question numbered 99 above, choose the best option from letters A - D that best completes the gap.
explanation: pets; a domestic or tamed animal kept for companionship or pleasure.

question: In question numbered 100 above, choose the best option from letters A - D that best completes the gap.
explanation: world; the earth, together with all of its countries and peoples.
